html:
Etymology[edit]

From lūxus (“dislocated”). Cognate with Ancient Greek λοξός (loxós, “slanting”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈluːk.soː/, [ˈlˠuːk.s̠oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈluk.so/, [ˈluk.sɔ]

Verb[edit]

lūxō (present infinitive lūxāre, perfect active lūxāvī, supine lūxātum); first conjugation

  1. I put out of joint, dislocate
  2. I displace

Descendants[edit]

  • Catalan: luxar
  • Portuguese: luxar
  • Spanish: luxar

Adjective[edit]

lūxō

  1. dative masculine singular of lūxus
  2. dative neuter singular of lūxus
  3. ablative masculine singular of lūxus
  4. ablative neuter singular of lūxus

References[edit]

  • luxo in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • luxo in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
